editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Iron Age: Contayning the Rape of Hellen: The ſiege of Troy: The Combate betwixt Hector and Aiax: Hector and Troilus ſlayne by Achilles: Achilles ſlaine by Paris: Aiax and Vliſſes contend for the Armour of Achilles: The Death of Aiax, &c. Written by THOMAS HEYVVOOD.
Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.

Of the party of the Grecians.

div.p: The Iron Age: Contayning the Rape of Hellen: The ſiege of Troy: The Combate betwixt Hector and Aiax: Hector and Troilus ſlayne by Achilles: Achilles ſlaine by Paris: Aiax and Vliſſes contend for the Armour of Achilles: The Death of Aiax, &c. Written by THOMAS HEYVVOOD.

figure.p: TAM ROBVR · TAM ROBOR. NI-COLIS ARBOR IOVIS. 1610.

div.p: Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.

list.head: Of the party of the Troians.
Of the party of the Grecians.
list.item: Caſtor and Pollux, the two brothers of Hellena.

div.head: To my VVorthy and much Reſpected Friend, Mr. Thomas Hammon, of Grayes Inne Eſquire.
div.p: IF the noble Scholler Nichod. Friſeelimus, thought that his labour in Transferring ſix of Ariſtophanes his Comedies, out of the Originall Greeke into the Roman tongue, was worthy to be dedicated to ſix ſeueral, the moſt eminent Princes of his time, for Learning and Iudgement: Thinke it then no diſparagment to you, to vndertake as well the Patronage, peruſall of this Poem: Which as it exceedes the ſtrict limits of the ancient Comedy (then in vſe) informe, ſo it tranſcends them many degrees; both in the fulneſſe of the Sceane, and grauity of the Subiect.

The Hiſtory whereon it is grounded, hauing beene the ſelected Argument of many exquiſite Poets▪ For what Pen of note, in one page or other
hath not remembred Troy, and bewayl'd the ſa • ke, and ſubuerſion of ſo illuſtrious a Citty▪ Which, although it were ſcituate in Aſia, yet out of her aſhes hath riſen, two the rareſt Phoenixes in Europe, namely London and Rom •
▪
• ir my acquaintance with your worth, and kn •••• dge of your iudgement, were the chiefe m • tiues, inducing me to ſelect you before many others: accept it, I intreate you, as fauourably as hee expoſeth it willingly, who as he hath antecedently long, ſo futurely euer,

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: COurteous Reader: The Gold, Siluer, and Braſſe Ages hauing beene many yeares • ince in the Preſſe, continuing the Hiſtory from Iupiters Birth (the ſonne of Saturne) to the Death of Hercules. This Iron Age (neuer till now Publiſhed,) beginneth where the other left, holding on, a plaine and direct courſe, from the ſecond Rape of Hellen: (For ſhe was in her minority rauiſhed by Theſeus the Friend of Hercules) not onely to the vtter ruine, and deuaſtation of Tro • ; but it, with the ſecond Part, ſtretcheth to the Deathes of Hellen, and all thoſe Kings of Greece, who were the vndertakers of that Ten yeares Bloody and fatall Seige. I preſume the reading there of ſhall not pr •• ue diſtaſtfull vnto any▪ Firſt inregar • of the Antiquity and Nobleneſſe of the Hiſtory: Next becauſe it includeth the moſt things of eſpeciall remarke, which haue beene ingeniouſly Commented, and labouriouſly Recorded, by the Muſes Darlings, the Po • ts: And Times learned Remembraneers; the Hiſtriographers▪

Laſtly, I deſire thee to take notice, that theſe were the Playes often (and not with the leaſt applauſe,) Publickely Acted by two Companies, vppon one Stage at once, and haue at ſundry times thronged three ſe
• erall Theaters, with numerous and mighty Auditories, if the grace they had then in the Actings, take not away the expected luſter, hoped for in the Reading, I ſhall then hold thee well pleaſed, and therein, my ſelfe fully ſatisfied; Euer remaining thine as ſtudious▪

div.head: Actus primus, Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter King Priamus, Queene Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, Aeneas, Deiphobus, &c.

sp.speaker: Priamus.
sp.l: PRinces and Sonnes of Priam, to this end
We • cal'd you to this ſolemne Parleance▪
There's a deuining ſpirit prompts mee ſtill▪
That if we new begin Hoſtility,
The Grecians may be forc't to make repayre
Of our twice r • in'd walls, and of the rape
Done to our ſiſter faire Heſio • e.
Aeneas. I am my princely Soueraigne of your minde,
And can by grounded arguments approoue
Your power and potency: what they twice demoliſh' • ,
Is • ow with ſtrength and beauty rear'd againe.
Your Kingdome growne more populous and rich▪
The youth of Troy irregular and vntam'd,
Couetous of warre and martiall exerciſe.
From you and ſiluer treſſed Hecuba
Fifty faire ſonnes are lineally deriu'd,
All Aſiaes Kings are in your lou • and league▪
Their royalties as of your Empire held▪
Hector and Hectors brothers are of power
To fetch your ſiſter from the heart of Greece,
Where ſhe remaines imbrac't by Telamon.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Aeneas, your aduiſe aſſents with vs.
How ſtand our ſonnes vnto theſe wars inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: In mine opinion we haue no iuſt cauſe
To rayſe new tumults, that may liue in peace:
Warre is a fury quickly coniured vp,
But not ſo ſoone appeaſed▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What iuſter cauſe▪
When the whole world takes note to our diſgrace,
Of this our Troy, twice rac't by Hercules.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And faire Heſione rapt hence to Greece,
Where ſhe ſtill liues coopt vp in Salamine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troy, was twice rac't, and Troy deſeru'd that wracke,
The valiant (halfe Diuine bred) Hercules,
Redeem'd this Towne from blacke mortality,
And my bright Aunt from death, when he ſurcharg'd
The vi • gin fedde, Sea-monſter with his club.
For my owne Grand-fire great La • medon,
Denied the Heroe, both the meede propos'd,
And moſt (ingratefull) ſhut him from the Gates:
Troy therefore drew iuſt ruine on it ſelfe:
Tis true, our Aunt was borne away to Greece,
Who with more iuſtice might tranſport her hence,
Then he whoſe priſe ſhe was? bold Telamon
For ventring firſt vpon the wals of Troy,
Alcides gaue her to the Salmine Duke.
Detayning her? whom keepes he but his owne?
Were ſhe my priſoner I ſhould do the like.
By Ioue ſhe's worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then of force,
Shee muſt be worth the fetching.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fe • ch her that liſt: my reuerent King and father▪
If you purſue this expedition,
By the vntaunted honor of theſe armes
• hat li • e imblazon'd on my burni • h't ſhield▪
It is without good cauſe, and I deuine
Of all your flouriſhing line, by which the Gods
haue rectified your fame aboue all Kings,
Not one ſhal liue to meate your Sepulchre,
Or trace your funerall Heralds to the Tombes
Of your great Auceſtours: oh for your honour
Take not vp vniuſt Armes.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Prince Hectors words
Will draw on him the imputation
Of feare and cowardeſie.

sp.speaker: ▪Troi.
sp.l: Fie brother Hector,
If our Aunts rape, and Troyes deſtruction̄
Bee not reueng'd, their ſeuerall blemiſhes
The aged hand of Time can neuer wipe
From our ſucceſſion.
'Twill be regiſtred
That all King Priams ſonnes ſaue one were willing
And forward to reuengs them on the Greekes,
Onely that Hector durſt not.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ha, durſt not didſt thou ſay? effeminate boy▪
Go get you to your Sheepe-hooke and your Scrip,
Thou look'ſt not like a Souldier, there's no fire
Within thine eyes, nor quills vpon thy chinne,
Tell me I dare not? go, riſe, get you gone:
Th'art fitter for young Oenons company
Then for a bench of ſouldiers: here comes one,
Antenor is returned.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Welcome Antenor, what's the newes from Greece?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Newes of diſhonour to the name of Priam,
Your Higneſſe Siſter faire Heſiones
(After complaint) when I propos'd your Maieſty
would fetch her thence perforce, had you but ſeen •
With what diſdainefull pride, and bitter taunts
They toſt my threats: 'twould haue inflam'd your ſplee ••
With more then common rage, neuer was Princeſſe
So baſely vſ'd: neuer Embaſſadour
With ſuch diſhonour ſent f om Princes Court,
As was thenfrom that of Telamons,
Of Agamemnons and the Spartan Kings.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: I ſhall not dye in peace, if theſe diſgraces
Li • c v • reueng'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: By Ioue wee'le fetch her thence,
Or make all populous Greece a Wilderneſſe,
Paris a hand, wee are friends, now Greece ſhall finde
And thou ſhalt know what mighty Hector dares.
When all th'vnited Kings in Armes ſhall rue
This baſe diſhonour done to Priams blood.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heare Gracious ſir, my dreame in Ida Mount,
Beneath the ſhadow of a Cedar ſleeping.
Celeſtiall Iuno, Ve • us, and the Goddeſſe
Borne from the braine of mighty Iupiter.
Theſe three preſent me with a golden Ball,
On which was writ, Detur pulcherrimae,
Giue't to the faireſt: Iuno proffers wealth,
Scepters and Crownes: ſaith, ſhe will make me rich▪
Next ſteps forth Pallas with a golden Booke,
Saith, reach it me, I'le teach the Litterature,
Knowledge and Arts, make thee of all moſt wiſe.
Next ſmiling Venus c • me, with ſuch a looke
Able to rai • ſh mankinde: thus beſpake mee,
Make that Ball mine? the faireſt Queene that breathes,
I'le i • requitall, caſt into thine armes.
How can I ſtand ag • i • ſt her golden ſmiles,
When beautie promiſt beauty? ſhee preuayl'd:
To her I gaue the priſe, with which ſhee mounted
Like to a Starre from earth ſhott vp to Heauen.
Now if in Greece (as ſome report) be Ladies
Peereleſſe for beauty, wherefore might not Paris
By Venus ayde ſayle • ence to Grecia,
And quit the rape of faire Heſion • ,
By ſtealing thence the Queene moſt beautifull▪
That feedes vpon the honey of that ay •• ?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That amorous Goddeſſe borne vpon the waue •
Aſſiſt thee in thy voyage, we will rigge
A royall flee • e to wa • t thee into Greece.
Aeneas with our ſonne Deiphobus,
And other Lords ſhall beare thee company.
What thinke our ſonnes Hector and Troylus
Of Paris expedition?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: As an attempt the Heauens haue cauſe to proſper.
Go brother Paris, if thou bring'ſt a Queene,
Hector will be her Champion; then let's ſee
What Greeke dare fetch her hence.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Sraight giue order
To haue his Fleet made ready.

div.stage: Enter Caſſandra with her haire about her eares.

sp.speaker: Caſſan.
sp.l: Stay Priam, Paris ceaſe, ſtay Troian Peeres
To p • ot you • vniu • rſall • uert • row.
What hath poore Troy deſe • u'd, that you ſhould kindle
• lames to deſtroy it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What intends Caſſandra▪

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: To quench bright burning Troy, to ſe • u • e thee,
To ſaue old Priam and his fifty ſonnes.
(The royal'ſt iſſue, that e're King I enioy'de)
To keepe the • euerent haires of Hecuba,
From being torne off by her owne ſad hands▪

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Caſſandra's madde.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: You are mad, all Troy is mad •• .
And railes before it's ruine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What would my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Stay this bold youth my brother, who by water
Would ſayle to b • ing fire which •• all bu • ne all T • oy.
Stay him, oh ſtay him▪ ere the •• golden roo • es
Melt o're our heads before theſe g • orious Turret •

Bee burnt to aſhe • . Ere cle • r •
Simois
• treames
Ru •• e with b • oud royall, and Scamander Plain • ,

In which Troy
•• ancis bee ma • e a Sepu • chre
To bury Troy, and Troians.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her, ſome falſe deuining ſpirit
Enuying the honour we ſhall gaine from Greece,
Would trouble our deſignements.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Royall ſir,
Caſſandra is a Veſtall Propheteſſe,
And conſecrate to Pallas; oft inſpir'd,
Then lend her gracious audience.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: So let our Aunt
Bee ſtill a ſlaue in Greece, and wee your ſon •••
Bee held as cowards.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let Antenors wrongs
Bee baſely ſwallowed, and the name of Troy
Be held a word of ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Then let Troy burne,
Let the Greekes clap their hands, and warme themſelues
At this bright Bone-fire: dream'd not Hecuba
The night before this fatall Youth was borne,
That ſhee brought forth a fire-brand?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: And when King Priam to the Preiſt reueal'd
This ominous dreame, hee with the Gods conſulted,
And from the Oracle did this returne,
That the Chi • de borne ſhould ſtately Iſlion burne.

sp.speaker: •• r.
sp.l: And well the Prophet gueſt, for my deſire

To viſi •
Greece, burnes with a quenchleſſe fire:
Not from this flaming brand ſhall I be free,
Till I haue left rich Troy, and Sparta ſee.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Yet Hecuba, ere thou thy Priam looſe,
And Priam ere thou looſe thy Hecuba,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Why ſpeakes not in this caſe Andromache?
Thou ſhalt looſe a Hector, who's yet thine.
Why good Aeneas doſt thou ſpeech forbeare?
Thou hop'ſt in time another Troy to reare,
When this is ſackt, and therefore thou ſtandſt mute,
All ſtrooke with ſilence; none aſſiſt my ſuite.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Force her away and lay her faſt in hold.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.l: Then Troy, no Troy, but aſhes; and a place
Where once a Citty ſtood: poore Priam, thou
That ſhalt leaue fatherleſſe fifty faire ſonnes,
And this thy fruitfull Queene, a deſolate widdow▪
And Ilium now no Pallace for a King,
But a confuſed heape of twice burnt bricke.
They that thy beauty wondred, ſhall admire
To ſee thy Towers de • ac'd with Greekiſh fire.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art no Sibill, but from fury ſpeak'ſt,
Not inſpiration we regua • d thee not.
Come valiant ſonnes, wee'le •• rſt prepare our ſhips,
And with a royall Fleete well rigg'd to ſea
Seeke iu • t reuenge for faire Heſtone.

div.stage:
Exeunt omnes, manet Paris, to him Oenon who in his g •
ign out p • ucks her backe.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Know you not mee?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: View mee well.
And what I am, my lookes and teares will teach thee▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oenon? what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: To ſee Ida bare
Of her • all Cedars, to ſee ſhipwrights ſquare
The trunks of new feld Pines: Asking the cauſe,
So many Hatchets, Hammers, Plowes and Sawes
Were thither brought: They gan mee thus to greete▪
With theſe tall Cedars we muſt build a fleete
For Paris; who in that muſt ſayle to Greece,
To fetch a new wife thence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And my faire Oenon,
Know that they told truth, for 'tis decreed
Euen by the Gods beheſt, that I ſhould ſpeed
Vpon this new aduenture: The Gods all,
That made mee iudge to giue the golden Ball.
The Winde blowes faire, fare-well.

sp.speaker: Oenon.
sp.l: Heare me one word.
By our firſt loue, by all our amorous kiſſes▪
Courtings, imbraces, and ten thouſand bleſſes
I coniure thee, that thou in Troy may'ſt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: They cry aboard, and Paris muſt away.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: What need'ſt thou plowe the ſeas to ſeeke a wife▪
Hauing one here, to hazard thy ſweete life,
Seeking a Strumpet through warres fiele • alarmes,
And haue ſo kind a wife lodg'd in thine armes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sweete Oenon, ſtay me not, vnclaſpe thine hold.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Not for Troyes crowne or all the Sun-gods Gold▪
Canſt thou? oh ca • ſt thou thy ſweete life indanger,
And leaue tnine owne wife to ſ • eke out a ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I can▪ farewell.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Oh yet a little ſtay.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Let go thine hold, or I ſhall force my way▪

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Oh do but looke on me, yet once againe.
Though now a Prince, thou waſt an humble ſwaine,
And then I was thine Oenon. (Oh ſad fate)
I craue thy loue, I couet not thy ſtate;
Still • am Oenon: ſtill thou Paris ar •
The ſelfe-ſame man, but not the ſelfe-ſame heart▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: V • tie, or I ſhall breake thy charming band,
N • ptune aſſiſt my courſe: thou Ioue my hand.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Moſt cruell, moſt vnkind, hadſt thou thus ſaid
The night before thou hadſt my Maiden-head▪
I had beene free to chuſe, and thou to wiue;
Not widdowed now, my husband ſtill aliue.

div.stage: Enter King Menelaus, King Diomed, Therſites, a Lord Embaſſadour with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: King Diomed, Sparta is proud to ſee you,
Your comming at this time's more ſeaſonable,
In that wee haue imployment for your wiſedome
And royall valour.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: The Chritian Scepter now in contr • uerſi •
(As this Embaſſadour hath late inform'd)
Deſpiſing that vſurping hand, which long
Hath againſt Law and Iuſtice ſwayd and borne it▪
Offers it ſelfe to your protection.
Is it not ſo my Lord?

sp.speaker: Embaſſa.
sp.l: You truely vnderſtand our Embaſie.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Menelaus!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What ſaith Therſites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: That Heauen hath many Starres in't, but no eyes▪
And cannot ſee deſert. The Goddeſſe Fortune
Is head-winkt, why elſe ſhould ſhe proffer thee
Another Crowne that hath one: (Grand Sir Ioue)
What a huge heape of buſineſſe ſhalt thou haue,
Hauing another Kingdome? being in Creete,
Sparta will go to wracke, being in Sparta,
Creete will to ruine: To haue more then theſe
Such a bright Laſſe as Hellen: Hellen? oh!
'Muſt haue an eye to her too, fie, fie, fie,
Poore man how thou'lt bee puſl'd!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Why thinkes Therſites my bright Hellens beauty
Is not with her faire vertues equaliz'd?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Yes, I thinke ſo, and Hellen is a • aſſe,
But thou beleeu'ſt ſo too.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Therſites is a rayler.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No, I diſclaim't, I am a Counſellor▪
I haue knowne a fellow matcht to a faire wife,
That hath had ne're a Kingdome: thou haſt two
To looke to, (ſcarce a houſe) thou many Pallaces,
Hee ſcarce a Page, and thou a thouſand ſeruants:
Yet hee hauing no more, yet had too much
To looke to one faire wife.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Were not the King
Well grounded in the vertues of his Queene,
Thy words Therſites might ſet odds betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: My Hellen? therein am I happieſt.
Know Diomed, her beauty I preferre
Before the Crownes of Sparta, and of Creete.
Muſicke! I know my Lady then is comming▪
To gi • e kind welcome to King Diomed,
Strowe in her way ſweete powders, burne Perfume,
And where my Hellen treads no feete preſume.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Twere better ſtrowe horne-ſhauings.

div.stage: Enter Hellen with waiting Gentlewomen and Seruants.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis told ys this Embaſſadour doth ſtay
To take my husband, my deare Lord away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: True Hellen, 'tis a Kingdome calls me hence.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: A Kingdome! hath your Hellen ſuch ſmall grace,
That you preferre a Kingdome 'fore her face?
You value me too cheape, and doe not know▪
The worth and value of the face you owe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I had rather haue a good Calues face.

sp.speaker: Heſ • .
sp.l: Theſeus, that in my non-age did aſſaile mee,
And being too young for paſtime, thence did haile me:
Hee, to haue had the leaſt part of your bliſſe
Oft proffered mee a Kingdome for a kiſſe.
You ſurfeit in your pleaſures, ſwimme in ſport,
But ſir, from henoeforth I ſhall keep • you ſhort.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Faire Queene, 'tis honour calls him hence away,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What's that to Hellen, if ſhee'le haue him ſtay▪
Say I ſhould weepe at parting, (which I feare)
Some for ten Kingdomes would not haue a teare
Fall from his Hellens eye, but hee's vnkind,
And cares not though I weepe my bright eyes blind.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Great King, we haue diſcouer'd from the ſhoare
A gallant Fleete of ſhips, that with full ſayle
Make towards the Port.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What number?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Some two and twenty Sayle.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l:
Diſcouer them more amply, and make good the Ha
• en againſt them, till we know th'intent of their arriue.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: My Royall Lord I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Embaſſadour this buſines once blowne o're,
You ſhall receiue your anſwer inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You ſhall not goe and leaue your Hellen here,
Can I a Kingdome gouerne in your abſence,
And guide ſo rude a people as yours is?
How ſhall I doe my Lord, when you are gone,
So many bleake cold nights to lye alone?
Y'haue vſ'd mee ſo to fellowſhip in bed,
That ſhould I leaue it, I ſhould ſoone be dead:
Troth I ſhall neuer indure it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My ſweete Hellen,
Was neuer King bleſt with ſo chaſte a wife.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The newes? whence is their Fleete?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The Generall?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Priams ſonne.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Their expedition?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: To ſeeke aduentures and ſtrange Lands abroad▪
And though now weather-beat, yet brauer men,
More rich in Iewells, coſtlier araide,
Or better featur'd ne're eye beheld,
Eſpecially the Prince their Generall,
Paris of Troy one of King Priams ſonnes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Brauer then theſe our Lacedemons are▪

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Madam, by much.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How is the Prince of Troy
To Menelaus mighty Spartans King?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Prince Menelaus is my Soueraigne Madam,
But might I freely ſpeake without offence,
(Excepting Menelaus) neuer breath'd
A brauer Gallant then the Troian Prince.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What Intertainment ſhall wee giue theſe ſtrangers?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What? but the choyce that Lacedemon yeelds,
If they come braue, our brauery let vs ſhow,
That what our Sparta yeelds, their Troy may know:
Let them not ſay they found vs poore and bare.
Or that our Grecian Ladies are leſſe faire
Then theirs: giue them occaſion to relate
At their returne, how wee exceede their ſtare.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Hellen hath well aduis'd, and for the beſt
Her counſell with our honour doth agree,
All Spartaes pompe is for the Troians free.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Oh had I known their Landing one day ſooner,
That Hellen might haue trim'd vp her attire
Againſt this meeting▪ then my radiant beauty
I doubt not, might in Troy be tearm'd as faire,
As through all Greece I am reputed rare.

div.stage: A flouriſh. Enter Paris, Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, Menelaus and Diomed embrace Paris and the reſt: Paris turnes from them and kiſſeth Hellen, all way ſhee with her hand puts him backe.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: 'Tis not the Spartan faſhion thus to greet
Vpon the lips, when royall ſtrangers meet • .
I know not what your Aſian Court-ſhip is.
Oh Ioue, how ſweetely doth this Troian kiſſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Beare with a ſtranger Lady▪ though vnknowne;
That's practis'd in no faſhion ſaue his owne.
Hee that his fault confeſſeth ne're offends▪
Nor can hee iniure, that no wrong intends,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: To kiſſe mee! why before ſo many eyes
The King could do no more: would fortune bring
This ſtranger there where I haue met the King▪

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Patience, ſweet Hellen, Troians welcome all,
You ſhall receiue the princelieſt entertaine
Sparta can yeeld you, but ſome late affaires
About the Cretan ſeepter calls vs hence,
That buſineſſe once determin'd wee are yours,
In the meane time faire Hellen bee't your charge
To make their welcome in my abſence large.

div.stage: They all go • off with a flouriſh, onely Paris and Hellen keepe the Stage.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh Ioue my dreame! ſweete Venus ayde my prayer▪
And keepe thy word: behold a face more faire
Then thou thy ſelfe canſt ſhewe, this is the ſame
Thou promiſt me in Ida, this I claime.
Giue me this face faire Ʋenus, and that's all
I'le aske in guerdon of the golden Ball.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Of what rare mettall is this Troian made?
That one poore kiſſe hath power ſo to perſwade,
Here at my lips the ſweetneſſe did beginne,
And ſince hath paſt through all my powers within:
Oh kiſſe mee if thou lou'ſt me once againe,
I feele the firſt kiſſe thrill through euery veine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Queene I muſt ſpeake with you,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Muſt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hellen, I,
I haue but two wayes to take, to ſpeake, or dye:
Grant my tongue pardon then, or turne your head
And ſay you will not, and ſo ſtrike me dead.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Liue and ſay on, but if your words offend,
If my tongue can deſtroy, you're neare your end.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh Ioue, that I had now an Angels voyce
As you an Angels ſhape haue, that my words
Might ſound as ſpheare-like muſicke in your eare.
That Ioue himſelfe whom I muſt call to witneſſe,
Would now ſtand forth in perſon to approoue
What I now ſpeake, Hellen, Hellen I loue.
Chide mee, I care not; tell▪ your husband, doe,
Feareleſſe of death, behold, I boldly woe▪
For let mee liue, bright Hellen to inioy,
Or let mee neuer backe reſayle to Troy:
For you I came, your fame hath hither driuen mee,
Whom golden Venus hath by promiſe giuen mee.
I lou'd you ere I ſaw you by your fame,
Report of your ra • e beauty to Troy came▪
But more then bruite can tell, or fame emblazon
Are theſe diuine perfections that I gaze on.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Inſolent ſtranger, is my Name ſo light
Abroad in Troy, that thou at thefirſt ſight
Shouldſt hope to ſtrum pet vs? thinks Priams ſonne,
The Spartan Queene can be ſo eaſily wonne?
Becauſe once Theſeus rauiſht vs from hence,
And did to vs a kind of violence:
Followes it therefore wee are of ſuch price,
That ſtolne hence once, we ſhould be rauiſh't twice?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That Theſeus ſtole you hence (by Heauen) I praiſe him,
And for that act I to the skies will raiſe him.
That hee return'd you backe by Ioue I wonder,
Had I bee • e Theſeus, hee that ſhould aſunder
Haue parted vs, and ſnatcht you from my bed:
Firſt from my ſhould ſhoulders haue tane this head.
Oh that you were the prize of ſome great ſtrife,
And hee that winnes might claime you as his wife,
Your ſelfe ſhould finde, and all the world ſhould ſee
Hellen, a priſe alone ordain'd for mee.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am not angry; who can angry be
With him that loues her? they that Paris ſee,
And heares the wonders and rare deedes you boaſt,
And warlike ſpoyles in which you glory moſt:
By which you haue attaind 'mongſt ſouldiers grace,
None can beleeue you that beholds your face.
They that this louely Troian ſee, will ſay;
Hee was not made for warre, but amorous plays

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Loue amorous Paris then.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My fame to endanger?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I can be ſecret Lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And a ſtranger?
Say I ſhould grant thee loue, as thou ſhouldſt clime
My long wiſht bed; if at th'appointed time
The Winde ſhould alter, and blow faire for Troy,
Thou muſt hreake off in midd'ſt of all thy Ioy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Not for great Spartaes Crowne, or Aſiaes Treaſure,
(That exceedes Spartaes) would I looſe ſuch pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: would it were come to that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your Husband Menelaus hither bring,
Compare our ſhapes, our youth and euery thing,
I make you Iudgeſſe, wrong me if you can:
You needes muſt ſay I am the properer man.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe that too.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then loue mee Lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Had you then ſett ſayle,
When my virginity, and bed to enioy
A thouſand gallant princely Suiters came?
Had I beheld thee firſt, I here proclaime,
Your feature ſhould haue borne mee from the reſt.
You come too late, and couet goods poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I came from Hellen, Hellens loue I craue,
Hellen I loue, and Hellen I muſt haue:
Or in this Prouince where I vent my mones,
I'le begge a Tombe for my exiled bones.

div.stage:
A flouriſh. Enter. Menelaus, Diomed, Therſites with Sparta •
Lords: Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, &c.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Now Prince of Troy, our buſineſſe being o're
This day in Lacedemon, you ſhall feaſt
Paris, wee are proud of ſuch a Princely gueſt.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Thus euery man is borne to his owne Fate.
Now it raines Hornes, let each man ſhield his Pate.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This royalty extended to the welcome
Of Priams ſonne, is more then Aſiaes King
Would yeeld vnto the greareſt Prince of Greece.
What is this Paris whom you honour ſo?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why askes my Queene?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: May not this proud▪ this beauty vanting Troian,
In a ſmooth browe hide blacke and rugged Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Hee ſuch an one? rather a giddy braine▪
A formall traueller. King Di • med
Your cenſure of this Troian?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: A Capring, Carpet Knight, a Cuſhion Lord,
One that hath ſtald his Courtly trickes at home,
And now got lea • e to publiſh them abroad
Did to a ſtranger Prince, it could not though
Lea • en my zeale o you: ſpeake the fayreſt Queene
That euer ſpake, this night ſhall we agree
To con ecrate to pleaſure and delights:
Your husband left me charge I ſhould inioy
All that the Court can yeeld: if all? then you
I would not for the world, but you ſhould doe
All that the King your Lord commands you too:
Your King and husband, you ſinne doubly ſtill
VVhen you aſſent not to obay his will:
Speake beauteous Q • eene. No? then it may be
Shee meanes by ſilence to accord with me:
I' • e trye that preſently, lend me your hand
Tis this I want, and by the Kings command
You are to let me haue it: more then this,
I want your lips to helpe me make a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh Heauen!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh loue, a ioy aboue all meaſure,
To touch theſe lips is more then heauenly pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Beſhrew your amorous rhetorick that did proue▪
My husbands will commanded me to loue,
For but for that iniun • tion, Paris know
I would not yeeld ſuch fauours to beſtow
On any ſtranger, but ſince he commands,
You may take more then eyther lips or hands.
Do I not bluſh ſweete ſtranger? if I breake
The Lawes of modeſt • , thinke that I ſpeake,
But with my husbands tongue, for I • ay ſtill
I would not yeeld, but to obey his will.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This night then without all ſuſpition,
The raniſhing pleaſures of your royall bed
You may a •• oord to Paris: bitter Therſites,
King Diomed, and your ſeruants may ſuppoſe
By my late counterfeite diſtemperature
I ayme at no ſuch happineſſe, alas
I am a puny Courtier, a weake braine,
• braine-ſicke young man; but Deuineſt Hellen,
VVhen we get ſafe to Troy.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To Troy?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes Queene, by all the gods it is decr • ed,
That I ſhould beare you thither; Priam knowes it,
And therefore purpoſely did rigge this Fleete,
To waft me hether; He and Hecuba,
My nine and forty brothers, Princes all
Of Ladies and bright Virgins infinite,
Will meete vs in the roade of Tenedos▪
Then be r • ſolu'd for I will caſt a plot
To beare you ſafe from hence!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This Troyan Prince
Will's more then any Prince of Greece dares pleade,
And yet I haue no power to ſay him nay:
VVell Paris I beſhrew you with my heart,
That euer you came to Sparta (by my ioy
Queene Hellen lyes, and longs to be at Troy:)
Yet vſe me as you pleaſe, you know you haue
My deareſt loue, and therefore cannot craue
VVhat Ile deny; but if reproach and ſhame
Purſue vs, on you Paris light the blame:
Ile waſh my hands of all, nor will I yeeld
But by compulſion to your leaſt demaund:
Yet if in lieu of my Kings intertaine,
You bid me to a feaſt aboord your ſhip,
And when you haue me there, vnknowne to me
Hoyſe ſayle, weigh Anchor, and beare out to Sea▪
I cannot helpe it, tis not in my power
To let fal ſayles, or ſtriue with ſtretching oares
To row me backe againe: this you may do,
But ſooth friend Paris He not yeeld thereto.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You ſhalbe then compell'd, o • me let all
The danger waiting on this practiſe fall.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l:
Castor and
• oll • x your two princely brothers
Are newly Landed, and to morrow next
Purpoſe for Lacedemon▪

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: On their approach
He lay my plot to eſcape away with Paris.
I haue it: you ſir for ſome ſpeciall reaſon
There comming keepe conceal'd, but when to morrow
You ſhal perceiue me neere the water port,
Euen when thou ſeeſt me ready to take Barge.
You apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Gracious Queene I do.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Take that farwel: now my fayre princely gueſt
All that belongs to you's to inuite Queene Hellen
Aboord your ſhip to morrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Spartaes mirrour,
Will you vouchſafe to a poore wandring Prince
So much of grace, will your high maieſty
Daigne the acceptance of an homely banquet
Aboord his weather beaten Barke?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: No Friend,
The King my husband is from Sparta gone,
And I, til his returne, muſt needes keepe home:
Vrge me not I intreate, it is in vaine
Get me aboord, Ile nere turne backe againe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nor ſhall you Lady, Sparta nor all Greece
Shal fetch you thence, but Troy ſhal ſtand as high
On tearmes with Greece, as Greece hath ſtood with Troy.

sp.speaker: Spa. L.
sp.p: This is the VVater-port, the Queenes royal gueſt, hath bound me to attendance, till the Prince and ſhee bee ready to take VVater: Methinkes in this there ſhould bee ſome tricke or other, ſhe was once ſtolne away by Theſeus, and this a gallant ſmooth fac'd Prince. The Kings from home, the Queenes but a VVoman, the Troi • ns ſhips new trim'd, the wind ſtands fayre, and the Saylors all ready abo • rd, ſweetemeates and wine, good words and opportunity, and indeede not what? If both parties bee pleaſde, but pleaſde or not the muſicke giues warning, are they not now vpon their entrance.

div.stage: Enter in state Paris, Hellen, Diomed, Th • r • i • es, Aeneas, Antenor, Deiphebus, &c. with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Health to your M • ieſties, your Princely brothers
Castor and Pollux, being within two Leagues
Of this great Citty, come to viſite you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My brothers ſtolne vpon vs vnawares.
Let me intreat • thee royall Di • med,
And you Therſites, d • me ſo much grace,
As giue them friendly meeting.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Queene we ſhall.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Our intertainment ſhall be giu • n aboord,
VVhere I preſume, they ſhall be welcome gueſts
To princely Paris.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: As to your ſelfe, faire Queene,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Set forwards then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: We'le hoyſe vp ſayle, neere to • eturne againe.

div.stage: Exeunt the Troians with a great ſhout.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Our brother Menelaus gone for Creete?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Our loue to ſee him, makes vs looſe much time▪
Yet all our labour is not vainly ſpent,
Since we ſhall ſee our ſiſter.

div.stage: Enter the Spartan Lord in hast.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.p: Princes, the Kings betray'd, all Greece diſhonoured, the Queene borne hence, the Troians haue weigh'd anchor, and with a proſperous gale they beare from hence:
sp.l: Shouting and hurling vp their caps for ioy,
They • rye farwel to Greece, amayne for Troy.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: The Queene borne hence, with that ſmooth traytor Paris.
See princes with what pride they haue aduanc'd
The Armes of Tray vpon their wa • ing pendants.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Rage not, but lets reſolue what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Let ſome ride poſt to Creete for menelaus.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: That be my charge.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: VVho'le after him to Sea?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That wil my brother Castor and my ſelfe,
And periſh there, or bring my ſiſter backe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Princes be't ſo, and fairely may you ſpeed:
Whilſt I to Agamemnon, great Achilles,
Vlyſſes, Nestor, Aiax, Idomean,
And all the Kings and Dukes of populous Greece,
Relate the wrongs done by this Rauiſher.
Part, and be expeditious▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
I ſmelt this Sea-rat ere he came a ſhoare, by this hee's grawing
Menelaus Cheeſe, and made a huge hole in't▪ Ship-dyet plea▪
ſeth 'boue all his Pallace banquets, much good doo't them:
They are at it without grace by this both bare:
Cuckold? no ſubiect with that name bee ſorry,
Since Soueraignes may be ſuch in all their glory.

div.head: Actus ſecundus Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Faire Creſida, by the honour of • y birth,
As I am Hectors brother, Priams ſonne,
And Troilus beſt belou'd of Hecuba,
As I loue Armes and ſouldiers, I proteſt,
Thy beauty liues inſhrin'd heere in my breſt.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: As I am Calchas daughter, Creſida,
High Prieſt to Pallas, ſhee that patrons Troy:
Now ſent vnto the Delphian Oracle,
To know what ſhal betide Prince Paris voyage.
I hold the loue of Troilus dearer farre.
Then to be Queene of Aſia.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Daughter to Calchas and the pride of Troy,
Plight me your hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Faire Heauen I doe.
Will Troilus in exchange grant me his too?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Yes, and faſt ſeal'd, you gods, your anger wreak
On him or her, that firſt this vnion breake.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: So proteſts Creſida, wretched may they dye,
That'twixt our ſoules theſe holy bands vntye.

div.stage: Enter Margaretan one of Priams youngest ſonnes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: My brother Troilus, we haue newes from Greece,
Prince Paris is return'd.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And with a priſe?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Aſia affoords none ſuch.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: What is ſhee worth our Aunt Heſione?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Or what might be her name?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Hellen of Sparta.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Hellens name
Hath ſcarce been heard in Troy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But now her fame
Will bee eterniz'd, for a face more faire
Sunne neuer ſhone on, nor the earth e re bare.
Why ſtay you here? by this Faris and ſhee
Are landed in the • ort of Tenedos,
There Priam, Hecuba, Hector, all Troy
Meets the mid-way to attend the Spartan Queene.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: In that faire Traine, my Creſid ſhal be ſeene
Of rarer beauty then the Spartan Queene.

div.stage: A flouriſh. Enter at one doore, Priam, Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, &c. At the other Paris, Hellen, Aeneas, Antenor, &c.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What Earth, what all mortality
Can in the height of our inuentions finde
To adde to Hellens welcome, Troy ſhall yeeld her.
Should Pallas, Patroneſſe of Troy deſcend,
Priam and Priams wife, and Priams ſonne •
Could not afford Her god-head more applauſe,
Then amply wee beſtow on Helena?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: We count you in the number of our daughters,
Nor can wee doe Queene Hellen greater honour.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I was not forward to hane Paris ſent,
But being return'd th'art welcome: I deſired not
To haue bright Hellen brought, but being landed,
Hector proclaimes himſelfe her Champion
'Gainſt all the world, and he ſhall guard thee ſafe
Deſpight all oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hectors word
As Oracle, hee'le ſeale it with his ſword.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And now my turne eomes to bid Hellen welcome.
You are no ſtranger here, this is your Troy,
Priam your father, and this Queene your mother:
Theſe be your valiant brothers, all your friends.
Why ſhould a teare fall from theſe heauenly eyes
Being thus round ingirt with your allyes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am I know not where, nor amongſt whom,
I know no creature that I ſee ſaue yon:
I haue left my King, my brothers, ſubiects, friends
For ſtrangers, who ſhould they forſake me now,
I haue no husband, father, brother neare:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hane you not all theſe, is not Paris heere?
Harke how the people hauing Hellen ſ • ene
Appland th'arri • all of the Spartan Queene:
And millions that your comming haue attended,
Amazed ſweare ſome Goddeſſe is deſcended.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: No way you can your eyes or body turne,
But where you walke the Prieſts ſhall Incenſe burne.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The ſacrificed beaſts the ground ſhall beate,
And bright religious fire the Altars heate.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nor feare the bruite of warre or threatning ſteel • ,
Vnited Greece wee value not.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Alone, by Hector is this Towne well man'd,
• ee like an Army againſt Greece ſhall ſtand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And who would feare for ſuch a royall wife
To ſet the vniuerſall World at ſtrife:
Bright Hellens name ſhall liue, and nere haue end,
When all the world about you ſhall contend.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Be as be may, ſince we are gone thus farre,
Proceede we will in ſpight of threatned warre,
Hazard, and dread? both theſe we nothing hold,
So long as Paris we may thus infold.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My father, mother, brothers, ſiſters all,
Iſli • m and Troy in pompe maieſticall,
Shall ſolemnize our nuptials. Let that day
In which we eſpouſe the beauteous Hellena,
Be held a holy-day, a day of ioy
For euer, in the Kalenders of Troy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo, we haue already ſent
Our high prieſt Calchas to the Oracle
At Delphos to returne vs the ſucceſſe,
And a true notice of our future warres,
Whilſt we expect his comming, be't our care,
The Spartans ſecond nuptials to prepare.

div.stage: Enter after an alarum, King Agamemnon, Menelaus Achilles, A • ax, Patroclus, Therſites, Calchas, &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Thou glory of the Greekes, the great commander
Of the ſtout Mirmedons: welcome from Delphos,
What ſpeakes the Oracle? the ſacke of Troy?
Or the Greekes ruine? ſay ſhal wee be victors,
Or Priam tryumph in our ouerthrow.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: The god of Delphos ſends you ioyful newes,
Troy ſhal be ſackt, and we be Conquerors:
Vpon your helmes weare triple ſpa • gled plumes:
Let all the lowdeſt inſtruments of warre,
With ſterne alarums rowſe the monſter death,
And march we boldly to the wals of Troy,
Troy ſhall be ſackt and we be conquerors.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Thanks for thy newes Achilles, by that honor
My father wonne vpon the wals of Troy.
I would not for the world, Priam ſhould ſend
Inceſtious Hellen backe on tearmes of peace.
May ſmooth Vliſſes and bold Diomed▪
Whom you haue ſent on your late Embaſſie,
Be welcom'd as Antenor was to Greece,
Scorn'd and reuil'd, ſince th' Oracle hath ſayd,
Troy ſhal be ſackt, and we be Conquerors.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: King Agamemnon heere's a Troian prieſt
Was ſent by Priam to the Oracle:
The reuerent man I welcome, and intreate
The General with theſe Princes, do the like.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Welcome to Agamemnon reuerent Calchas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To Menelaus welcome.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: To Aiax welcome: father canſt thou fight
As wel as pray, if we ſhould want for men?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: By prayers I vſe to fight, and by my counſel
Giue ayde to Armes.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Such as are paſt armes, father Calchas ſtill,
Say counſels good, but giue me ſtrength at will,
When you with all your Counſel, in the field
Meete Hector with his ſtrength, tel me who'le yeeld?

sp.speaker: Aga,
sp.l: The ſtrong built walls of ſtately Tenedos
We haue leuel'd with the earth. It now remaines
We march along vnto the wals of Troy,
And thunder vengeance in King Priams eares,
Had we once anſwere of our Embaſſie.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I euer held ſuch Embaſſies as baſe,
The reſtitution of our rauiſht Queene
On termes of parley bars our ſterne reuenge,
And ends our VVar ere fully it beginne.
King Agamemnon no, Aiax ſayth no,
VVhoſe ſword as thirſty as the parched earth,
Shal neuer ride in peace vpon his thigh,
Whilſt in the towne of Troy there breathes a ſoule
That gaue conſent vnto the Spartans rape:
March, march, and let the thunder of our drummes
Strike terrour to the Citty Pergamus.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: The ſonne of Telamon ſpeakes honourably,
Wee haue brought a thouſand ſhip • to Tenedos,
And euery ſhip full fraught with men at Armes:
And all theſe armed men with fiery ſpirits
Sworne to reuenge King Menelaus wrongs,

And burne sk •
▪kiſſing Iſl •• m to the ground.
Therefore ſtrike vp warres Inſtruments on hye,
And march vnto the Towne couragiouſly.

div.stage: In their march they are met by Vlyſſes and King Diomed, at which they make a ſtand.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Princes, what anſwere touching Hellena?

sp.speaker: Di • .
sp.l: What anſwere but d ſhonourable tearme?
Contempt and ſcorne pearcht on their leaders browes,
By Ioue I thought they would haue ſlaine vs both.
If euer Hellen bee redeem d from thence
But by the ſacke of Troy, ſay Diomed
Is no true ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Vlyſſ.
sp.l: Euen in the King
There did appeare ſuch high maieſticke ſcorne
Of threatned ruine, that I thinke himſelfe
Will put on Armes and meete vs in the field:
Wee linger time great Agamemnon, march,
That we may buckle with the pride of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam ſo inſo • ent, his ſonnes ſo braue
To intertaine ſo great Embaſſadou • s
With ſuch vngentle vſage.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: They haue a Knight cal'd Hector, on whoſe valour
They build their proud defiance, if I meete him,
Now by the azurd Armes of that bright goddeſſe
From whom I am deſcended, with my ſword
I'le loppe that limbe off, and inforce their pride
Fall at Achilles feete, Hector and I
Muſt nor both ſhine at once in warres bright Skie.

sp.speaker: • iax
sp.l: When they both meete, the greater dimme the leſſe,
Great Generall, march, Aiax indures not words
So well as blowes, in a field glazd with ſwords.

div.stage: Enter to them in Armes, Priam, Hector, Troilus, Paris, A • neas, Antenor, Deiphobus, &c.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Calchas a Traitour?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And amongſt the Greekes?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Baſe runagate wretch, when we their Tents ſurpriſe,
As Hector liues the traiterous Prophet dies.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let not remembrance of ſo baſe a wretch
Make vs forget our ſafety, th' Argiue Kings▪
Are landed, and this day rac't Tenedos:
And bid vs battaile on Scamander Plaines.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Whom we will giue a braue and proud affront;
Shall we not brother Hector?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troilus yes,
And beate a fire out of their Burgonets
Shall like an earthy Commet blaze towards Heauen
There grow a fixt ſtarre in the Firmament
To emblaze our laſting glory: Harke their Drums,
Let our Drummes giue them parleance.

div.stage: A parlie. Both Armies haue an enter-view.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is there amongſt your troopes a fellon Prince
Cal'd by the name of Paris?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is there amongſt your troopes a Knight ſo bold
Dares meete that Paris ſingle in the field,
And call him fellon?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or inſulting Greeke,
Is there one Telamon, dares ſet his foote
To Paris (here hee ſtands) and hand to hand
Maintaine the wrongs done to Heſione,
As Paris ſhall the rape of Helena.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Know here is one cal'd Aiax Telamon,
Behold him well, ſonne to that Telamon:
Thou faine would'ſt ſee, and hee dares ſet his foot
To Paris or thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou durſt not.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Dare not?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or if thou durſt, by this my warlike hand
I'le make thine head fall where thy foot ſhould ſtand:
And yet I loue thee cuze, know thou haſt parlie'd
With Troian Hector.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Were't thou ten Hectors, yet withall thy might
Thou canſt not make my head fa • l to my feete,
By Ioue thou canſt not cuze.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I much haue heard
Of ſuch a Knight cal'd by the name of Hector,
If thou bee'ſt hee whoſe ſword hath conquerd Kingdomes,
Pannonia, ll • yria, and Samothrace,
And to thy fathers Empire added them:
Achilles as a friend wils thee to ſheath
Thy war • ike ſword, retire from Troyes defenc •
And ſpare thy precious life, I would not haue
A Knight ſo fam'd meete an vntimely graue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I meet thee in that honourable loue,
And for thine owne ſake wiſh thee ſafe aboord.
For if thou ſtayeſt thou ſonne of Peleus,
I'd haue thee know thy fame is not thine owne,
But all ingroſt for mee; not all thy guard
Of warlike Mirmidons can wall i •• a • e
From mighty Hector.

sp.speaker: Di • .
sp.l: Shame you not great Lords
To talke ſo long ouer your menacing ſwords?

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: Alarme then for Gree • e and Helena.

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: As much for vs, for Troy and Hecuba.

div.stage: A great alarme and excurſions, after which, enter Hector and Paris.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Oh brother Paris, thou haſt this day lodg'd
Thy loue in Hectors ſoule, it did me good
To ſee two Greeksſh Knights fall in their blood
Vnder thy manly arme

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My blowes weretouches
Vnto theſe ponderous ſtroakes great Hector gaue.
Oh that this generall quarrell might be ended
In equall oppoſition, you and I
Againſt the two moſt valiant.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I will try
The vertue of a challenge, in the face
Of all the Greekes I will oppoſe my ſelfe
To ſingle combate, hee that takes my gage
Shall feele the force of mighty Hectors rage.

div.stage: A turne. Both the Armies make ready to ioyne battaile, but Hector ſteps betwixt them holding vp his Lance.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Heare mee you warlike Greekes, you ſee theſe fields
Are all dyde purple with the reeking gore
Of men on both ſides ſlaine, you ſee my ſword
Glaz'd in the ſanguine moyſture of your friends.
I call the ſonne of Saturne for a witneſſe
To Hectors words I haue not met one Grecian
Was able to withſtand mee, my ſtrong ſpirit
Would faine be equal'd: Is there in your Troupes
A Knight, whoſe breſt includes ſo much of valour
To meete with Hector in a ſingle warre?
By Ioue I thinke there is not: If there be?
To Him I make this proffer; if the gods
Shall grant to him the honour of the day,
And I be ſlaine; his bee mine honoured Ar mes,
To hang for an eternall Monument
Of his great valour, but my mangled body
Send backe to Troy, to a red funerall pile.
But if hee fall? the armour which hee weares
I'le lodge as Trophies on Apolloes ſhrine,
And yeeld his body to haue funerall rights.
And a faire Monument ſo nee • e the S • a,
That Merchants flying in their ſayle-wing'd ſhips
Neere to the ſhoare in after times may ſay▪
There lies the man Hector of Troy did ſlay,
And there's my Gantler to make good my challenge.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Will none take vp his gage? ſhall this proud challenge
Bee Intertain'd by none? I know you all
Shame to deny, yet feare to vndertake it:
The cauſe is mine, and mine ſhall be the honour
To combat Hector.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Menelaus pawſe,
Is not Achilles here, ſterne Aiax here,
And Kingly Diomed▪ how will they ſcorne,
That ſtand vpon the honour of their ſtrength,
ſhould you preuent them of this glorious combat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: By Ioue I thinke they dare as well take vp
A poyſonous Serpent as great Hectors gage.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Yes Troian, ſee'ſt thou not Aeacides
Dart emmulous lookes on Kingly Diomed,
Leaſt hee ſhould ſtoope to take his Gantlet vp.
And ſee how Diomed eyes warlike Aiax,
Aiax, Vlyſſes: euery one inflam'd
To anſwere Hector.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is there any here
Dares ſtoope whilſt great Achilles is in place?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And ſo dare I.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: You are all too weake
To incounter with the mighty Hectors arme,
This combat ſoly doth belong to mee.

sp.speaker: Aiax
sp.l: Then wherefore do'ſt not thou take vp the Gantlet?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: To ſee if thou or any bolder Greeke
Dare be ſo inſolent to touch the ſame,
And barre me of the honour of the combat.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: By all the gods I dare.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: And all the diuells
I'le loppe his hands off that dares touch the gage.

sp.speaker: Ʋlyſſ.
sp.l: Pray leaue this emulous fury: Agamemnon,
To end this difference, and prouide a Champion
To anſwers Hectors honourable challenge
Of nine the moſt reputed valiant:
Let ſeuerall Lots be caſt into an Helme,
Amongſt them all one priſe, he to whom Fortune
Shall giue the honour: let him ſtraight be arm'd
To incounter migdty Hector on this plaine.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: It ſhal be ſo you valiant ſonnes of Priam:
Conduct your warlike Champion to his Tent,
To breath a while, and put his armour on:
No ſooner ſhal the priſe be drawne by any,
And our bold Champion arm'd, but a braue Herald
Shall giue you warning by the trumpets ſound,
Till when we will retire vnto our Tents.
As you vnto the Towne.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Faint hearted Greekes,
Draw lots to anſwere ſuch a noble challenge,
Had great Achilles caſt his Gauntlet downe
Amongſt King Priams ſonnes, the weakeſt of fifty
Would in the heate of flames, or mouth of Hel,
Anſwere the challenge of ſo braue a King.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Greekes to your Tents, to put armour on;
Make haſt, • long to know my Champion.

div.stage: Flouriſh. Enter aboue vpon the wals, Priam, Heeuba, Hellena, Polixena, Aftianax, Margareton. with attendants.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Here from the wals of Troy, my reuerent Queene,
And beautious Hellen, we will ſtay to ſee
The warlicke combate 'twixt our valiant ſonne,
And the Greekes champion. Young Aſtianax,
Pray that thy father may haue Victory.

sp.speaker: Aſti.
sp.l: Why ſhould you doubt his fortune? whoſe ſtrong arme
Vnhorſt a thouſand Knights all in one day;
And thinke you any one amongſt the Greekes
Is able to incounter with his ſtrength?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But howſoeuer child, vnto the pleaſure▪
Of the high gods, we muſt referre the combate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My royall father, Hector in his armes
Sends for your bleſſing, with the Queene my mother,
And craues your prayers to the all powerful gods,
To grant him victory.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Bleſt may he be with honor, all my oriſons
Shall inuocate the gods for his ſucceſſe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I almoſt had forgot faire Hellena;
Dart me one kiſſe from theſe high battlements
To cheere him with: thanks queen theſe lips are charms
Which who ſo fights for, is ſecure from harmes.

div.stage: Heralds on both ſides▪ the two Champions Hector and Aiax appeare betwixt the two Armies.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: None pre •• e too neere the Champions.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Heralds on both ſides, keep the ſouldiers back.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now Greekes let me behold my Champion.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Tis I, thy couſen Aiax Telamon.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: And Cuz, by Ioue thou haſt a braue aſpect,
It cheeres my blood to looke on ſuch a foe:
I would there ran none of our Troian blood
Inall thy veines, or that it were diuided
From that which thou receiueſt from Telamon:
Were I aſſured our blood poſſeſt one ſide,
And that the other; by Olimpicke Ioue,
I'd thrill my Iauelin at the Gresian moyſture,
And ſpare the Troian blood: Aiax I loue it
Too deare to ſhed it, I could rather wiſh
Achilles the halfe god of your huge army,
Had beene my oppoſite.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Hee keepes his Tent
In mournful paſſion that he miſt the combate:
But Hector, I ſhal giue thee cauſe to ſay,
There's in the Greekiſh hoaſt a Knight a Prince,
As Lyon hearted, and as Gyant ſtrong
As Thetis ſonne: behold my warlicke Target
Of pondrous braſſe, quilted with ſeauen Oxe hides,
Impenetrable, and ſo ful of weight,
That ſcarſe a Grecian (ſane my ſelfe) can lift it:
Yet can I vſe it like a Summers fan,
Made of the ſtately traine of Iuno's bird:
My ſword will bite the hardeſt Adamant.
I'le with my Iauelin cleaue a rocke of Marble:
Therefore though great Achilles be not here,
Thinke not braue couſen Hector but to finde,
Achilles equal both in ſtrength and minde.

div.stage: Alarum, in this combate both hauing loſt their ſwords and Shields. Hector takes vp a great peece of a Rocke, and caſts at Aiax; who teares a young Tree vp by the rootes, and aſſailes Hector, at which they are parted by both armes.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hold, you haue both ſhed blood too deare to looſe,
In ſingle oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is your Champion,
My couſen Aiax willing to leaue combate;
Will hee firſt giue the word.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Sir Paris no,
'Twas Hector challenge, and 'tis Hectors office,
If we ſurceaſe on equal termes of valour,
To giue the word.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Then here's thy couſins hand,
By Ioue thou haſt a luſty pondrous arme:
Thus till we meete againe, lets part both friends;
For proofe whereof Aiax we'le interchange
Somewhat betwixt vs, for alliance ſake:
Here take this ſword and target, truſt the blad,
It neuer deceiu'd his maiſter.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Take of me
This purple ſtudded belt, I won it couſen
From the moſt valiant prince of Samothrace:
And weare it for my ſake.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Priam vnto the Greekiſh General
This profer makes. Becauſe theſe blood-ſtayn'd fields
Are ouer-ſpread with ſlaughter, to take truce
Till all the dead on both ſides be interr'd:
Which if you grant, he here inuites the Generall,
His nephew Aiax, and the great Achilles,
With twenty of your chiefe ſelected Princes,
To banquet with him in his royal Pallace:
Thoſe reuels ended, then to armes againe.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: A truce for burying of the ſlaughtred bodies
We yeeld vnto: but for our ſafe returne
From Troy and you, what pledges haue you found?

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: You ſhal not need more then the faith of Hector
For Priams pledge, King Agamemnon take
My faith and honour, which if Priam breake,
Ile breake the heart of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: We'le take your honor'd word, this night we'le part,
To morrow morning when ſit hower ſhal call,

We'le meete King Priam
• eere his Citties wall.

div.head: Actus Tertius Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Braue time, rare change, from fighting now to feaſting:
So many heauy blades to flye in peeces
For ſuch a peece of light fleſh? what's the reaſon?
A Laſſe of my complexion, and this feature
Might haue bin rapt, and ſtolne agayne by Paris,
And none of all this ſtirre for't: but I perceiue
Now all the World's turn'd wenchers, and in time
All wenches will turne witches: but theſe Trumpets
Proclaime their enter-view.

div.stage: A flouriſh. Enter all the Greekes on one ſide, all the Troians on the other: Euery Troian Prince intertaines a Greeke, and ſo march two and two, diſcourſing, as being condu • ted by them into the Citty.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: See here's the picture of a polliticke ſtate,
They all imbrace and hugge, yet deadly hate:
They ſay their are braue Laſſes in this Troy.
What if Therſites ſprucely ſmug'd himſelfe,
And ſtriu'd to hide his hutch-backe: No not I.
Tis held a rule, whom Nature markes in ſhow
And moſt deformes, they are beſt arm'd below.
I'le not conceale my vertues: yet ſhould I venter
To damme my ſelfe for painting, fanne my face
With a dyde Oſtritch plume, paſter my wrinkles
With ſome old Ladies Trowell, I might paſſe
Perhaps for ſome maide-marrian: and ſome wench
Wanting good eye-ſight, might perhaps miſtake me
For a ſpruce Courtier: Courtier? tuſh, I from
My firſt diſcretion haue abhor'd that name,
Still ſuiting my conditions with my ſhape,
And doe, and will, and can, when all elſe • ayle:
Though neither ſooth nor ſpeak wel: brauely rayle,
And that's Therſites humour.

div.stage: Lowd Muſi • ke. A long table, and abanquet in ſtate, they are ſeated, a Troian and Greeke, Hecuba, Polixena, Creſida, and other Ladies wa • te, Calchas is preſent whiſpering with his Daughter Creſida.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: After ſo much hoſtility in ſteele,
All welcome to this peacefull intertaine.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam wee know thee to be honourable,
Although ou • foe Treaſon is to be fear'd
In Peſants not in Princes.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Ey ſo, now • it a Troian and a Greeke.
Couſin Ai • x neere mee, you are next in bloud,
And neere mee you ſhall ſit: the ſtrayne of honour
That makes you ſo renown'd, ſprong from He • i • n • .
Tis part of Hectors bloud, your groſſer ſpirits
Leſſe noble are your father Telamons.
Welcome to Troy, and Hector, welcome all:

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: In Troy thy kinſman, but in field thy foe:
Thy welcome Couſin here I pay with thanks,
The truice expir'd, with buffets blowes and knocks.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: For that wee loue the Cuze.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Me thinks this Troian Hector
Out ſhines Achilles and his poliſht honours
Ecclipſeth our bright glory, till he • ſet
W ee cannot riſe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: King Menelaus, we were once your gueſt,
You now are ours, as welcome vnto Troy,
As we to Sparta.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: But that theſe our tongues
Should be as well truce bound as our ſharpe weapons,
We could be bitter Paris: but haue done.

sp.speaker: Vlyſſ.
sp.l: Menelaus is diſcreet, ſuch haynous wrongs
Should be diſcours'd by Armes and not by tongues.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why doth Achilles eye wander that way?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is that a Troian Lady?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Shee is.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Of vs.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Her name?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Polyxena.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Polixena? ſhe hath m • lted vs within,
And hath diſſolu'd a ſpirit of Adamant.
Shee hath done more then Hector and all Troy,
Shee hath ſubdu'de Achilles.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In one word this Troy ſhall be ſackt and ſpo •• 'd,
For ſo the gods haue told mee, Greece ſhall conquer,
And they be ruin'd, leaue then imminent perill,
And flye to ſafety.

sp.speaker: Creſ.
sp.l: From Troilus?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: From deſtruction, take Diomed and liue,
Or Troilus and thy death.

sp.speaker: Creſ.
sp.l: Then Troilus and my ruine.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is Creſid mad?
sp.p: Wilt thou forſake thy father, who for thee and for thy ſafety hath forſooke his Countrey?

sp.speaker: Creſ.
sp.l: Muſt then this Citty periſh?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Troy muſt fall.

sp.speaker: Creſ.
sp.l: Alas for Troy and Troilus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Loue King Diomed
A Prince and valiant, which made Empha •• s
To his Imperiall ſtile, line Diomeds Queene,
Be briefe, ſay quickly wilt thou? is it done?

sp.speaker: Creſ.
sp.l: Diomed and you i'le follow, Troilus ſhun.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Bee't Aiax, or Achilles, that Greeke ly • s
Who ſpeakes it, i'le maintaine it on his perſon.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ha Aiax!

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: We ſpeake it, and dares Troilus fay we lie?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And weare it Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Dar'ft thou make't good?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: On Diomed, or the boldeſt Greeke
That euer manac'd Troy excepting none.

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: None?

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Excepting none.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Kings of Greece.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Princes of Troy.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles bafled?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: And great Aiax bran'd?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: If great Achilles, Aiax, or the Diuel braue Troilus, hee ſhall braue and buffer thee.

sp.speaker: P • i.
sp.l: Sonn •• .

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Fellow Kings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: As wee are Priam and your father.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: As wee are Agamemnon Generall
Turne not this banquet to a Centaus feaſt,
If their be ſtrife debate it in faire termes,
Show your ſelnes gouern'd Princes.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Wee are appeas▪d.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Wee ſatisfied, if Hector be ſo.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How grew this ſtrife?

sp.speaker: Hect
sp.l: I know not, onely this I know.
Troilus will maintaine nothing againſt his honour,
And ſo farre, be it through the heart of Greece,
Hector will backe him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So will Paris too.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Mildly diſcourſe your wrongs, faire Princes do • .

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed maintaines his valour thus,
He ſaith it was his Launce diſmounted Troilus,
And not the ſtumbling on the breathleſſe courſe
Of one new ſlaine that feld mee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis falſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: • ar.
sp.l: It was my fortune to make good that field,
And hee fell iuſt before mee, Diomed then
Was not within ſixe ſpeares length of the place.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How Troian rauiſher?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Call mee not Cuckold maker,
I care not what you terme me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brooke this wrong.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Say'ſt thou mee ſo madde Greeke?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Gouerne you Kingdomes Lords, and cannot ſway
Your owne affection?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris, forbeate.
Mildly diſcourſe, and gently wee ſhall heare.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I ſay King Diomed vnhorſt not Troilus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How came I by his horſe then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: As the vnbackt courſer hauing loſt his rider,
Gallopt about the field you met with him,
And catch'd him by the raine.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Here was a goodly act
To boaſt on, and ſend word to Creſida.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Was no Prince neare when I encountred Troilus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I was, and ſaw the ſpeare of Diomed
Tumble downe Troylus but peruſe his armour▪
The dint's ſtill in the vainbrace.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Bee't ſo or not ſo, at this time forbeare
To vrge extreames. Kings let this health go round,
Pledge me King Priam in a cupful crown'd.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Now after banquet, 〈◊〉 Muſicke ſtrike
A pirhicke ſtraine, we are not all for warre,
Souldiers their ſtormy ſpirits can appeaſe,
And ſometimes play the Courtiers when they pleaſe.

div.stage: A lofty dance of ſixteene Princes, halfe Troians halfe Grecians.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I haue obſerued Achilles, and his eye
Dwels on the face of faire Polixena.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Why is not Hellen here at this high feaſt?
I haue ſweat many a drop of blood for her,
Ye • neuer ſaw her face.

sp.speaker: Achi
sp.l: I could loue Hector, what's our cauſe of quarrel?
For Hellens rape? that rape hath coſt already
Thouſands of ſoules, why might not this contention
'Twixt Paris and the Spartan King be ended,
And we leaue Troy with honour.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles how?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Fetch Hellen hether, ſet her in the midſt
Of this braue ring of Princes, Paris here,
And Menelaus heere: ſhe betwixt both:
They court her ore againe, whom ſhe elects
Before theſe Kings, let him inioy her ſtill,
For who would keepe a woman gainſt her wil?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The names of wife and husband, th'interchange
Of our two bloods in young Hermione,
To whom we are ioynt parents, Hellens honor
All pleade on my part, I am pleaſde to ſtand
To great Achilles motion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So are we.
All that I haue for comfort is but this,
That in the day I ſhow the properer man,
Ith'night I pleaſe her better then hee can.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Are all the Greecian Kings agreed to this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are, we are.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Place the two riuals then, each bide his fate▪
And vſher in bright Hellen in all ſtate.

div.stage: The Kings promiſcuouſly take their places, Paris and Menelaus are ſeated oppoſite, Hellen is brought in betwixt them by Hecuba and the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh that I were (but Hellen) any thing▪
Or might haue any obiect in my eye
Saue Menelaus: when on him I gaze,
My errour chides mee, I my ſhame emblaze.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Oh Hellen, in thy cheeke thy guilt appeares,
More I would ſpeake, but words are drown'd in teares,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: A gallant Queene, for ſuch a royall friend
What mortall man would not with Ioue contend?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Hellen the time was I might call thee wife,
But that ſtile's changed; I▪ thou thy ſelfe art chang'd
From what thou waſt: and (moſt inconſtant Dame)
Haſt nothing left thee, ſa • e thy face and name.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And I both theſe haue: haſt thou not confeſt
Faire Hellen, thy exchange was for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What can our Sparta value?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Troy.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: You erre.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: who breathes that Sparta would 'fore Troy prefer.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thou haſt left thy father Tendarus.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: To gayne
King Priam, Lord of all this princely trayne.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thy mother Lada thou haſt left who mournes▪
And with her piteous teares laments thy loſſe:
Cannot this mooue thee?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh I haue left my mother.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No Hellen, but exchang'd her for another:
Poore L • da, for rich He • uba, a • are Queene
For the great Aſian Empreſſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: From Castor and from Poll • x thou haſt rang'd
Thy naturall brothers.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No, but chang'd,
For Hector, Troilus, and the royall ſtore
Of eight and forty valiant brothers more.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If nothing elſe can moue thee Helena,
Thinke of our daughter young Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My deare Hermione.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Canſt thou call her deare▪
And leaue that iſſue which thy wombe did beare?
Shee's ours betwixt vs, ca • ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Can ſhee? knowing,
A ſweeter babe within her ſweete wombe growing
Begot laſt night by Paris.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Looke this way Hellen, ſee my armes ſpread wide,
I am thine husband, thou my Spartan bride.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Hellen, this way turne thy ſight,
Theſe are the armes in which thou layeſt laſt night.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh how this Troian tempts mee!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This way wife,
Thou ſhalt ſaue many a Greeks and Troians life▪

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I know it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This way turne thine head,
This is the path that leades vnto our bed.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And 'tis a ſweete ſmooth path.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take this way Hellen, this is plaine & eue • .

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That is the way to hell, but this to Heauen:
Bright Comet ſ • ine this way.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Cleare ſtarre ſhoot this▪
Here honour dwels.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here many a thouſand kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way I ſhould, becauſe I know 'tis 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Welcome.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But I'le this way for Paris kiſſes ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And may I dye an Eunuch if ere morne
I quit thee not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brooke this ſcorne,
Grecians to Armes.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Then Greece from Troy deuide,
This difference armes, not language moſt decide.

sp.speaker: All Greekes.
sp.l: Come to our Tents.

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: And wee to man the towne.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Theſe Tents ſhall ſwimme in bloud.

sp.speaker: Greekes.
sp.l: Blood Troy ſhall drowne.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Yet ſhall no ſtroke fall from Achilles arme,
Faire Polixena, ſo powerfull is thy charme.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: My riuall in the loue of Creſida.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Falſe Creſida, iniurious Diomed.
Now ſhall I prooue in hoſtile enter-change
Of warlike blowes that thou art all vnworthy
The loue of Creſid.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why cam'ſt thou not on Horſe-backe▪
That Diomed once againe diſmounting thee
Might greete his Lady with another courſe
Wonne from the hand of Troilus.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Diomed,
By the true loue I beare that trothleſſe Dame
I'le winne thee, and ſend thy Horſe and Armour
Vnto the Tent of Creſid guard thy head,
This day by mee thou ſhalt be captiue led.

div.stage: Alarme. They fight and are parted by the army▪ Diomed looſeth his Helmet.

sp.speaker: Troi
sp.l: Another Horſe for Diomed to flye,
Hee had neuer greater neede then now to runne.
Though hee be fled yet Troilus this is thine.
My Steed hee got by ſleight, I this by force.
I'le ſend her this to whom hee ſent my horſe.

div.stage: Enter Aeneas and Achilles reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is this the anſwere of the note I ſent
To royall Priam and Queene Hecuba,
Touching their daughter bright Polixena?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Behold Queene Hecubaes hand, King Priams ſeale,
With the conſent of faire Polixena,
Condition'd thus, Achilles ſhall forbeare
To dammage Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Returne this anſwer backe,
Tell Priam that Achilles Arme's benumb'd,
And cannot lift a weapon againſt Troy.
Say to Queene Hecuba wee are her ſonne,
And not Achilles, nor one Mirmidon
Shall giue her leaſt affront, as for the Lady
Bid her preſume, we henceforth are her Knight,
And but for her, Achilles ſcornes to fight.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Then thus ſaith Priam, but reſtraine thy powers,
And as hee is a King, his daughter's yours.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Achilles, where's Achilles, what vnarm'd,
when all the Champaigne where our battailes ioyns,
• s made a ſtanding poole of Greekiſh blood▪
Where horſes plung d vp to the ſaddle skirts▪
And men aboue the waſte wade for their lines,
And canſt thou keepe thy Tent?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My Lute Patroclus.

div.stage:
A great Alarme. Ente •
Aga • lemnon.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let Greekes, kill Greekes, let's bend vnnaturall armes
Againſt our owne breſts, ere the conquering Troians
Haue all the honour of this glorious day.
Can our great Champion touch a womaniſh Lute,
Aud heare the grones of twenty thouſand ſoules
Gaſping their laſt breath?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: I can.

div.l: Reſcue, ſome reſcue, the red field is ſtrowd
With Hectors honours and young Troilus ſpoyles.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Yet all this moues not me.

sp.speaker: Ʋlyſſ.
sp.p: How long hath great Achilles bin ſurnam'd Coward in Troy, that Hector, Troilus, Paris, haue all that name ſo currant in the • r mouthes?
sp.l: I euer held him valiant, yet will Achilles fight?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Vlyſſes, no,
Beneath this globe Achilles hath • o foe.

sp.speaker: Vlyſſ.
sp.l: Then here vnarm'd be ſlaine, think'ſt thou they'l ſpare
Thee more then vs?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Or if thou wilt not arme thee,
Let thy Patroclus lead thy Mirmidons,
And weare thy Armour.

sp.speaker: Vlyſſ.
sp.l: Thy Armour is ſufficient▪
Without thy preſence being fear'd in Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: To ſaue our oath and keepe our Tents from ſacke,
Patroclus don our Armes, lead forth our guard,
And wearing them by no Prince be out-dar'd.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles honours me, what heart can feare,
And great Achilles ſword proofe Armour weare?

div.stage: Exeunt all the Princes, enter Therſites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Where's this great ſword and buckler man of Greece?
Wee ſhall haue him one of ſneakes noiſe,
And come peaking into the Tents of the Greeks,
With will you haue any muſicke Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Baſe groome, I'l teare thy fleſh like falling Snow▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: If I had Hectors face thou durſt not doo't.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Durſt not?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Durſt not, hee's in the field, thou in thy Tent,
Hector playing vpon the Greekiſh burgonets,
Achilles fingring his effeminate Lute.
sp.p: And now becauſe thou durſt not meete him in the field, thou haſt counterfeited an humour of loue. Achilles?
Thou the Champion of Greece, a meere bug-beare▪ a ſcar-crow, a Hobby-horſe.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Vliſſes taught thee this, deformed ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Coward thou durſt not do this to Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: On thee Ile practiſe, til I meete with him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Aiax is valiant, and in the throng of the Troians,
Achilles is turn'd Fidler in the Tents of
The Grecians.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Diomed wounded, bringing in Patroclus dying.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Looke here Achilles.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Patroclus?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: This wound great Hector gaue:
Reuenge my death, before I meets my graue.

sp.speaker: Vliſ.
sp.l: Yet will Achilles fight? ſee Aiax wounded,
Two hundred of thy warlike Mirmedons
Thou haſt loſt this day.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Let's beate him to the field.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Had I loſt a Patroclus, a deere friend
As thou haſt doue, I would haue doud theſe armes
In which he dyed, ſprung through the Troian hoaſt,
And ma • ger oppoſition, let the blow
Or by the ſame hand dy'd: come ioyne with me,
And we without this picture, ſtatue of Greece,
This ſhaddow of Achilles, will once more
Inuade the Troian hoaſt.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Aiax?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Wee owe thee for this ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I ſcorne that debt:
Thou haſt not fought with Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My honor and my oath both combate in mee:
But lone ſwayes moſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Our ſhips are fir'd, fiue hundred gallant veſſels▪
Burnt in the Sea, halfe of our Fleete deſtroy'd,
Without ſome preſent reſcue.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Doth no man aske where is this double fire,
That two wayes flyes towards heauen?
Vpon the right our royall Nauy burnes,
Vpon the left, Achilles Tents on fire.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Our Tent?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: By Ioue thy Tent, and all thy Mirmedons,
